title: 109_s1165
content: The Act may be cited as the "James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge Expansion Act of 2005". Congress finds that the United States Fish and Wildlife Service manages the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge to promote the recovery of 4 endangered Hawaiian waterbirds. They lease 240 acres of wetland habitat and have a contract to purchase the land to protect the habitat and improve Refuge management. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has identified approximately 800 acres of high-value wildlife habitat owned by the estate of James Campbell for inclusion in the Refuge. The land features coastal dunes, wetlands, and coastal strand that support various threatened and endangered species, including Hawaiian waterbirds, migratory shorebirds, waterfowl, seabirds, native plant species, monk seals, and green sea turtles. Expanding the Refuge will provide increased opportunities for wildlife-dependent public uses, including wildlife observation, photography, and environmental education. Acquisition of the land will create a single, large, ecologically-intact unit with buffer land to reduce impacts on the Refuge and prevent flood damage in the town of Kahuku. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The term "Refuge" refers to the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge established under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Expansion of the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge to include approximately 1,100 acres of land, with the Secretary having the authority to make minor boundary modifications to achieve conservation goals or facilitate property acquisition. The map depicting the expansion is available for inspection at a designated office of the US Fish and Wildlife Service. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service, as directed by the Secretary, will publish a notice in the Federal Register and local publications regarding the availability of a map for the expansion of the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge by approximately 1,100 acres. The Secretary may acquire land for the Refuge, to be administered according to law. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose.
